awd_titl_txt: Measuring Gravity at the Micron Scale with Laser-Cooled Trapped Microspheres: a Continuation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Gravitational Physics and the Atomic, Molecular and Optical Experimental Physics programs. Gravity is by far the least understood fundamental force of nature. One particular mystery has to do with why gravity is so much weaker than the other Standard Model forces in nature. As a number of recent theories have suggested, important clues related to this "hierarchy problem" can be obtained by measuring how gravity behaves at sub-millimeter distances. Such measurements could lead to exciting new discoveries of physics beyond the Standard Model. However, the gravitational force between massive objects becomes weak very rapidly as their size and separation distance decreases, thus making ultra-sensitive measurements a necessity at sub-millimeter length scales. This group is developing an experiment based on new technology which could advance our understanding of gravity by several orders of magnitude at the micrometer length scale. In this approach, a fused silica test mass is suspended in a "container" made of light, leading to greatly reduced friction and enhanced sensitivity. The students and postdoctoral researchers working on this project will be broadly trained in experimental physics and nanofabrication and will be well positioned for entry into the scientific workforce. The fundamental nature of this project appeals to our sense of wonder about the natural world.  The nation will benefit from an improved understanding of high-energy physics related to gravitational physics at the micron-length scale, at a fraction of the cost of particle-collider experiments.

This award supports an experiment which uses laser-cooled trapped microspheres to test for Yukawa-type deviations from Newtonian gravity at the micron length scale. By optically levitating the force sensor, an exquisite de-coupling from the environment is possible, yielding sub aN-Hz^1/2 force sensitivity at room temperature. This new technique could ultimately advance our understanding of gravity at the micron length scale by a factor of 1,000 to 100,000, and may lead to ground-breaking discoveries. In addition to studies of short-range gravitational forces, the proposed experimental technique will also enable novel investigations of Casimir forces in unexplored regimes. The project is conceptually divided into three tasks: (1) refinement of techniques to position levitated nanospheres within few-micron distances from a source mass surface, (2) investigation of systematic errors in preliminary gravity measurements, (3) in-parallel development of novel methods for trapping and cooling the levitated nanoparticles, including sympathetic cooling with cold atoms. One graduate student, one undergraduate student, and one postdoctoral researcher will be broadly trained in experimental physics and nanofabrication, and encouraged to present results at scientific meetings. By participating in this highly interdisciplinary research project, students will be well equipped for scientific careers. In addition, efforts to include women and minority researchers in the project will be undertaken.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit:

The fact that the strength of the gravitational force is so much weaker than that of the other Standard Model forces (electromagnetism, the strong nuclear force, and the weak nuclear force) is known as the gauge hierarchy problem. Theoretically, this necessitates a mysterious extreme fine-tuning of parameters in the Standard Model of particle physics in order to explain the mass of the Higgs boson, first observed at the Large Hadron Collider not even a decade ago. However, as a number of recent theories have suggested, important clues related to this ``hierarchy problem'' can be obtained by measuring how gravity behaves at sub-millimeter distances. Such measurements could lead to exciting new discoveries of physics beyond the Standard Model, in the form of gravitational inverse square law (ISL) violations at short-range. However, the gravitational force between massive objects becomes weak very rapidly as their size and separation distance decreases, thus making ultra-sensitive measurements a necessity at these length scales.  The best experimental constraints to date on such ISL violations at length scales between 1mm and 1um come from precision torsion balance experiments, sensitive micro-cantilever measurements, and investigations of the Casimir effect.

 In this project we have studied the viability of another type of sensor which could be useful for measurements of gravity at the micron scale, namely optically levitated dielectric microspheres. By optically levitating the force sensor in high-vacuum, an exquisite decoupling from the environment is possible, yielding sub-aN force sensitivity at room temperature. This new technique could ultimately advance our understanding of gravity at the micron length scale by many orders of magnitude.

At high vacuum we have demonstrated calibrated force sensing at the zeptonewton (10-21N) level using optically trapped nanoparticles in a standing wave trap. The sensitivity achieved exceeds that of any conventional room-temperature solid-state force sensor by over an order of magnitude, which should be sufficient sensitivity for improved measurements of gravity at the micron scale by at least 3 orders of magnitude. We estimate that ten times further improved sensitivity can be attained with reduced laser noise at similar pressures. Although micron range tests of gravity require extreme sensitivity, they also require an understanding of background forces and sources of systematic error, which often limit such measurements in practice.

In this project, we have made improvements to our experiment designed to investigate micron-range gravitational-like interactions between a 300-nm diameter silica nanosphere test mass and a microfabricated source mass attractor. The nanosphere is trapped in an optical standing wave retro-reflected from a nearby thin membrane surface. The mirror surface is electrically conducting, acting as a shield for electromagnetic background forces, and the source mass attractor can be positioned at micron distances behind the membrane. The next step in the experiment is investigation of systematic errors in preliminary gravity measurements. To improve our capability to characterize such background forces, we have demonstrated a new type of scanning force trap which is able to reliably position and scan a nanoparticle at micron distances near a surface.  The scanning approach we have developed provides a new tool to study systematics which could lead to non-newtonian gravity searches with much improved sensitivity at distances down to hundreds of nanometers, far below the distance scale of other leading searches for example involving torsion balances.

This work has resulted in 3 publications in refereed journals, 3 additional manuscripts submitted for publication in refereed journals, and 30 presentations (26 invited, 4 contributed) at conferences, workshops, universities and national labs.

Broader Impact:

Two PhD students, one undergraduate senior thesis, and one postdoctoral scholar were supported by this award, including one student and postdoc that are members of an under-represented group (Hispanic physicists). The students working on this project learned valuable techniques which make them attractive future members of the scientific workforce. Their training included optics, vacuum technology, lasers, computer-aided design and modeling, nanofabrication, electronics, data acquisition, and data analysis. The technology being developed in this project will have other impacts in the general area of precision force sensing. In addition to tests of gravitational physics at short length scales, such technology may also be useful for gravitational wave detection, magnetic field sensing, electric field sensing, or inertial sensing.
